stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on Course 15’s space-colony/plantation sub-area: improving platform readability with glow outlines, adding/reshaping low-poly crops and farm props (water tanks, machinery), testing speedrun routes (including PLJ/BLJ behavior) and validating performance on real N64 hardware. He also discusses broader project philosophy: designing gameplay first, then story; and making a ROM hack that can stand on its own as a “real game.”
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete design/UX decisions (platform borders, jank-jump avoidance, optional routes), a reproducible crash tied to PLJ/BLJ behavior, real-hardware performance profiling, and several documentary-useful statements about ROM hacks as standalone games and gameplay-first storytelling.

findings.summary: Kaze pitches a potential monetized marathon format: a 30-day stream building a full major Mario 64 hack in real time, with donations extending the schedule (e.g., every $500–$1,000 adds an extra day), explicitly framed as for income rather than charity.
Course 15’s concept is a “space colony” with a plantation/greenhouse: bumpers and dense platforming are justified diegetically as farm infrastructure (crops, machinery, water tanks, silos).
Readability pass: Kaze agrees platform edges can be hard to see and decides to add glowing outlines/borders across “The End”/space level platforms to clearly communicate safe surfaces and boundaries.
He focuses on reducing “noisy visuals” while improving navigation clarity, adding signage pointing toward the factory and calling out the need for clearer borders and less visual clutter.

He identifies and wants to remove or redesign a specific platforming segment that feels like a “jank jump,” prioritizing fun, readable jumps over awkward precision, and considering adding an intermediate platform to smooth difficulty.

Kaze avoids making diagonal wall-jumps required because many players can’t execute them; he prefers optional challenge routes (intended path vs “newbie strategy” vs long-jump bypass) that preserve freedom without gating progress behind advanced tech.

Testing speedrun movement, Kaze confirms PLJ/BLJ-style shortcuts are possible in this area, but reproduces a crash that appears to be caused by an infinite loop in his PLJ-related code rather than level geometry. He believes it will be straightforward to fix due to easy reproduction.
He notes BLJs are “untouched” (not intentionally supported), but current behavior can still crash; he concludes he may need to explicitly support BLJ/related edge cases to prevent unintended crashes.

Real hardware profiling: after uploading to an N64, he measures ~43 FPS in the plantation section and observes the scene “doesn’t like all these plants,” implying the crop density is a performance bottleneck on console.
He uses Fast64 (Blender add-on) and a direct-to-N64 upload workflow to test console performance; he also notes emulator play can have noticeable input lag compared to hardware.

Lighting system plan: he intends to read collision types from the collision map to drive contextual glow/lighting under Mario (matching an effect already present in another area), and add point lights so Mario visually reacts to local lighting.

He troubleshoots a star/object blinking effect: discovers material/prim-color state is being overwritten somewhere, then implements a working blink by correcting RGBs and export/import steps; the blink speed is tuned for readability.

Skybox/background technique: Kaze references a custom function (“RainbowPG,” shared previously on SimpleFlips Discord) for programmable backgrounds that are cheaper than “normal” Mario 64 backgrounds, using fewer textures and saving memory. His skybox is a separate box that follows the camera by a configurable percentage (e.g., 100% for distant space, 95% for a nearer oil rig).
Story approach: he prefers building solid gameplay first and then writing story around it, arguing it fits Mario-style games better than story-first development.
findings.quote: We haven’t really planned the story yet. I think it’s better to just put together some gameplay first, and then plan the story around the gameplay you have. Because it’s a Mario game.

findings.summary: He wants “Return to Yoshi’s Island” to be respected as a real game, playable without nostalgia/context for Mario 64, and pushes back on the idea (from another ROM hacker he spoke with) that ROM hacks can’t stand on their own.
findings.quote: I definitely want to change that. I want to make sure that this ROM hack is also playable as a normal game without the context of Mario 64.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions Doriel wanted a sound clip of Kaze sneezing for a “compact” they’re working on, implying ancillary media/promo assets being produced alongside development.
Longtime supporter resubscribes (90 months) and gifts multiple subs; says they are “working on all the decoms,” prompting Kaze to point them toward the Fast64 Discord as a central hub for new tech.
Kaze says he previously posted his background function (“RainbowPG”) on SimpleFlips Discord for others to copy, reflecting informal knowledge-sharing pipelines in the scene.
ZeroVolt appears in chat (greeting only); no specific music-conversion work discussed in this stream.
Chat prompts readability feedback (“platforms need more clear borders”), which directly influences Kaze’s decision to add glowing outlines to platforms across the level.

key_stories.title: PLJ/BLJ shortcut discovery and a reproducible crash
key_stories.summary: While testing the Course 15 plantation sub-area, Kaze explores potential speedrun lines and confirms players can PLJ/BLJ over intended routes for major shortcuts. During repeated attempts, the game crashes, which he determines is likely caused by an infinite loop in his PLJ-related code rather than the level’s triangles.
key_stories.challenge: Keep advanced movement tech (PLJ/BLJ) from destabilizing the game while still allowing interesting shortcuts.
key_stories.process: He repeatedly reproduces the crash via the same shortcut attempt, reasons about likely causes (not level geometry), and concludes he must explicitly handle BLJ/PLJ edge cases instead of leaving them as accidental behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Crash is considered easy to reproduce and therefore fixable; he accepts that explicit support may be required to avoid unintended crashes while preserving speedrun freedom.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s clearly something in the PLJ code itself causing an infinite loop somewhere.

key_stories.title: Making space platforms readable with glow outlines
key_stories.summary: Kaze receives feedback that platform borders are unclear against the space background. He decides to implement glowing outlines across platforms in the space/end level to standardize readability and reduce visual ambiguity during platforming.
key_stories.challenge: Players may misread edges and fail jumps due to low contrast/unclear borders.
key_stories.process: He compares areas where boundaries are readable (existing blue glow) vs unclear edges, then commits to adding a consistent glow-outline language across all platforms.
key_stories.outcome: A clear visual rule is established: platforms in this level will use glow rims/borders for navigation clarity.
key_stories.key_quote: What I’m going to do is… I’m going to have glowing outlines on all the platforms in The End.

key_stories.title: Real N64 performance check reveals plant-density cost
key_stories.summary: Kaze uploads the build to real N64 hardware to test performance in the plantation section. The framerate reads around 43 FPS and he observes the scene struggles specifically when many plant objects are visible.
key_stories.challenge: Maintain visual richness (crops/props) while staying within N64 performance budgets.
key_stories.process: He switches from emulator to console testing via a direct upload workflow, reads the framerate, and visually identifies dense plants as the likely culprit.
key_stories.outcome: Actionable optimization target: reduce/LOD/merge plant geometry or adjust draw distance/overdraw for crop-heavy views.
key_stories.key_quote: Ooh, it doesn’t like all these plants here.

key_stories.title: A cheaper programmable background/skybox system
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains and references his custom programmable background approach (“RainbowPG”), which he says is cheaper than typical Mario 64 backgrounds and saves memory. His skybox is a separate object that follows the camera by a tunable percentage to simulate distance.
key_stories.challenge: Create visually rich, scalable backgrounds without heavy texture/memory costs.
key_stories.process: He recalls the function name and where he posted it (SimpleFlips Discord), explains the camera-follow percentage trick (100% for far space, 95% for nearer environments), and compares it to standard skybox practices.
key_stories.outcome: A repeatable technique for RTYI’s varied environments that balances aesthetics and N64 constraints.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s also a lot cheaper… because you don’t have nearly as many textures, and it saves a lot of memory as well.

key_stories.title: Defining RTYI as a standalone game, not a “Mario 64 mod”
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes a recent conversation with another ROM hacker who believed ROM hacks can’t stand on their own. Kaze rejects that premise and frames RTYI’s goal as a complete, self-sufficient game experience that earns respect beyond the Mario 64 fanbase.
key_stories.challenge: Overcoming internal scene skepticism that ROM hacks are inherently lesser or context-dependent.
key_stories.process: He articulates the difference between simply reusing Mario’s movement as the entire value vs designing a cohesive game, and positions RTYI as an attempt to raise the bar.
key_stories.outcome: A clear creative north star for interviews: RTYI is built to be judged as a game first, hack second.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s depressing if you are living your life like that.

open_questions.topic: PLJ/BLJ crash root cause and policy
open_questions.context: Kaze can reproduce a crash when using PLJ/BLJ-like shortcuts and suspects an infinite loop in his movement-code handling. He says he didn’t explicitly support BLJ and may need to.
questions: What exact code path causes the infinite loop/crash during PLJ/BLJ attempts, and how did you ultimately fix it?
Do you want to officially support BLJ/PLJ in RTYI, limit it, or treat it as an emergent speedrun feature—why?
How do you test movement exploits for stability without removing the ‘Mario 64’ feel speedrunners expect?

open_questions.topic: Course 15’s narrative role and the ‘space plantation’ concept
open_questions.context: Kaze describes the level as a space civilization growing crops, but also says story isn’t planned yet and will be written around gameplay.

How did the plantation/greenhouse idea emerge, and what references (sci-fi, real-world agriculture, other games) shaped it?
When you later ‘planned story around gameplay,’ what story beats did this level end up supporting?

open_questions.topic: Visual readability rules for the space/end levels

open_questions.topic: Programmable backgrounds (‘RainbowPG’) and skybox camera-follow percentages
open_questions.context: Kaze explains a cheaper background method, fewer textures, memory savings, and a skybox cube following the camera at 95–100% depending on desired distance.
questions: Can you walk through the origin of the RainbowPG technique—what problem forced you to invent/use it?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he plans to open-source the game, and believes leaking only causes people to play a worse unfinished version; he’d prefer not to publicize leaks.
